text: Hi, everyone.
I'm Rachel Arnett.

Today, I'm excited to share
some research with you

that I'm doing in collaboration
with my amazing doctoral

students Serenity Lee, Keana
Richards, and Pat Hewlin.

So the focus of
the talk today is

on hidden challenges of minority
racial and ethnic identity
management at work.

And so we're trying to address
a common dilemma that I think

many in this room
have also examined,

which is, how do you
navigate a minority

racial or ethnic
identity at work?

And when we think
about this, we tend

to think about this occurring on
one of two ends of a continuum.

On one end, you have
high manifestation,

which is proactively
bringing attention
to your identity at work.

And on the other end,
you have suppression,

which is going out of your
way to actively withhold

or downplay things
related to your identity.

And one of the ways that we're
looking to build on this work

is to say that maybe rather
than these being two ends

the same continuum,
they are actually

two distinct dimensions of
manifestation and suppression.

We show this through
confirmatory factor analysis,

but we also show this by looking
at the unique antecedents that

precede these different types of
identity management strategies.

So manifestation is
preceded by perceptions

that bringing attention
to your identity

has benefits such as the ability
to feel authentic or enact

social change,
whereas suppression

is preceded by perceptions of
risks such as stigma and norm
violation.

But where we really see
ourselves contributing

and showing the value of
these two distinct dimensions

is by examining
the consequences.

So past work has shown
that suppression--

and we find as well
in our research--

that suppression is associated
with greater emotional burden

and likelihood of leaving
one's organization.

And manifestation is usually
thought of as sort of a panacea
to these issues.

It can decrease
emotional burden,

increase well-being,
and therefore increase
job commitment.

What we're going to be
looking at in this research--

the possibility that
sometimes manifesting

your identity actually
increases emotional burden
and the propensity to leave.

And we're particularly
going to look

at this under a
certain circumstance

by interacting manifestation
and suppression.

So what we're
hypothesizing here is

that for people who
feel a strong need

to suppress their identity
at least on some occasions,

higher levels of
manifestation will actually

further exacerbate emotional
burden and turnover.

And so what this looks
like is that the highest

emotional burden and
propensity for turnover

occurs among people
who vacillate back

and forth between
manifestation and suppression
depending on the scenario.

And as an example
from our data, this

is a woman who talks
about how her company has

a history of retaliation
and discrimination
against women of color.

So she doesn't feel like
she can bring attention

to her identity in the workplace
among upper administration.

But among students
of color that she's

trying to make feel welcome,
she feels like she can really
talk about her experiences.

And so we find support
for these hypotheses
across a few studies.
I'll just show two today.

But what we essentially
find is a similar pattern

where, among people
who don't really

feel a need to
suppress very much,

manifestation is either
unrelated to or negatively

related to emotional
exhaustion or other forms
of emotional burden.

But among people who
feel the need to suppress

at least sometimes, greater
manifestation actually

leads to more
emotional exhaustion

such that people who
are most exhausted

are those who vacillate back
and forth between manifestation

and suppression depending
on the scenario.

In a longitudinal study that we
just finished data collection

on this week, we also
find that the people who

vacillate back and forth
are the most anxious,

the most stressed, and the
ones who feel most ambivalence.

And we find through
moderated mediation

that these emotional
burdens do contribute

to a greater propensity to
leave one's organization.

And so what does this
mean for organizations?

Well, to understand what
do we do about all this,

we have to go back
to these antecedents.

What is the source and
root of this issue?

A lot of organizations
today are increasingly

trying to encourage people to
see the benefits of bringing

their authentic
selves to work or are

trying to enact social
change but don't really

know how to do
it, and so they're

enlisting the help of
racial and ethnic minorities

to figure out how to
be more effective.

All of these are
encouraging people

to bring their identities
to work by highlighting
the benefits of doing so.

What we're trying to
say in this research

is that highlighting
benefits is actually not

the same as mitigating
the risk of doing so.

And so long as organizations are
constantly bringing attention

to these benefits and
not actually addressing

the risk of bringing
attention to your identity

in the workplace,
they're actually

just making a more uncomfortable
situation potentially

for racial and ethnic
minority employees wherein

they feel constantly uncertain
about what is acceptable,

vacillating back and forth
between the situation,

and exhausting themselves in the
process, and then, as a result,

wondering whether
it's even worthwhile

to be in these organizations
in the first place.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
